title: Redesigned Buildings Offer Hope for Radical Progress
sub_head: Perhaps there is something wrong with the way architects and advocates for radically improved buildings are making the case.
body:
In “‘Green’ Buildings Struggles to Catch On” (U.S. News, Dec. 26), you report that 27 out of 19,000 building design firms met net-zero challenge goals. The politically correct article concludes by pointing a finger at tenants, investors and regulators.
Perhaps there is something wrong with the way architects and advocates for radically improved buildings are making the case.
Many politicians are advocating a radical transformation of American infrastructure. With hardly any architects, engineers or scientists in Congress, and in a country with the lowest ratio of engineers to lawyers in the world, what are the chances of radical initiatives or of megaprojects being permitted in the near term? Net zero.
If we really want progress, not just social approval, we need to stop preaching to the choir and start listening respectfully to the nonbelievers.
Felix DeVito
